thread.title_full: St. Charles legalizes video gambling — if state pays share - Chicago Tribune

author: Alexa Aguilar
title: St. Charles legalizes video gambling — if state pays share - Chicago Tribune
text:
Mayor Ray Rogina broke the tie Monday night in favor of legalizing video gambling in St. Charles. But some residents aren't happy about the vote.
Robert Brown, of St. Charles, said he would work to replace the mayor and five alderman who voted in favor of the measure.
"We want to be pride of the Fox," Brown said. "We want to be a beautiful community that draws people in … We don't want to be video gamblers."
In the 5-5 vote, with Rogina acting as the tie-breaker, the St. Charles City Council cast its final vote after months of debate about whether the city should allow video gambling machines in its bars and restaurants.
Committee approves video gambling in St. Charles Alexa Aguilar St. Charles is poised to approve video gambling at its next City Council meeting after another long committee meeting Monday night in which both sides made their plea.
Aldermen voted 5-4 to advance a measure to allow video gambling at St. Charles bars and restaurants that receive a gaming license...

(Alexa Aguilar) "Video gaming will only be divisive if people allow it to be," Rogina told the assembled crowd.
Alderman did add the caveat that video gambling would only be legal if the state passes a budget and that municipalities continue to receive their 1/6th share of the proceeds.
The state collects 30 percent of the net income from the gambling machines, but is supposed to forward 5 percent of that amount to the municipality where the gambling takes place.
In Darien, which first opposed video gambling when the state approved it in 2009 and eventually allowed it at seven locations, reported earlier this month that the state is behind in paying municipalities their share because of the budget stalemate in Springfield.
Darien's budget for this fiscal year forecasts $75,000 in tax revenue from video gambling. Officials there approved video gambling after businesses requested the change and members changed on the City Council.
Elmhurst committee split on video gambling Graydon Megan Those on both sides of the video gambling issue left Tuesday's meeting of the Public Affairs and Safety Committee disappointed, as committee members failed to reach a consensus on the issue, throwing the matter to the full City Council for debate.
That is expected to happen at the council meeting...

(Graydon Megan) Monday's vote in St. Charles was abrupt, with little discussion from the aldermen and public comment allowed only after the vote was already taken. Previous meetings lasted for hours, as proponents and opponents voiced their opinions. They fell into two camps: those who felt the money would provide a boost to local businesses and those who said that gambling could create social problems and didn't fit with St. Charles reputation as family friendly.
The residents who spoke Monday said they were disappointed by the vote, and St. Charles' image is now tarnished. But the mayor disagreed.
"As to the assumption of the impact on the town's image, I have been blunt in my response: this town's image cannot be tarnished," Rogina said, adding that the council has made and moved on from emotional and controversial decisions, such as voting for the Red Gate bridge or allowing Lazarus House, the town's homeless shelter, to be downtown.
Video slot machines spin through some suburbs Kimberly Fornek Video gambling is alive and well in the western suburbs.
Darien had seven places with video gambling licenses, Oakbrook Terrace had nine and Countryside had 17 as of the end of August.
For the businesses that installed video poker and slot machines, the gambling has brought in additional revenue.

... (Kimberly Fornek) Most of the aldermen who voted in favor have previously said they did so because of the dire forecast from the state about decreased money coming to municipalities. Those projections mean the city has to look elsewhere for funds, the aldermen said.
St. Charles staff have projected that the city could receive more than $100,000 if it allowed the machines in its bars and restaurants.
Alexa Aguilar is a freelance reporter for the Chicago Tribune. Kimberly Fornek, a Pioneer Press reporter, contributed to this report.
